journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Parenteral and Enteral Nutrition

title-group.article-title: Do Dietary Supplements Have Beneficial Health Effects in Industrialized Nations
title-group.subtitle: What Is the Evidence?

contrib-group.aff: Department of Medicine and the Nutrition Study Group, Eastern Virginia Medical School, Norfolk, Virginia, USA

author-notes.corresp: Paul E. Marik, MD, FCCP, FCCM, FACP, ABPNS, Department of Medicine and the Nutrition Study Group, Eastern Virginia Medical School, 825 Fairfax Ave, Suite 410, Norfolk, VA 23507, USA; e-mail: marikpe@evms.edu

abstract.p: Background: Dietary supplements are regularly used by at least half of the American population, yet the health benefits of these agents are unclear. Objective: A systematic review to determine the benefits and risks of dietary supplements in Westernized societies. Data Sources: MEDLINE, Embase, Cochrane Register of Controlled Trials and citation review of relevant articles. Study Selection: Randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trials in non-pregnant Westernized adults that evaluated clinical outcomes of nutritional supplements. Data Extraction: Data were abstracted on study design, study size, study setting, patient population, dietary intervention and clinical outcomes. The outcome of each study was classified as non-beneficial, beneficial or harmful according to whether theend-point(s) of interest reached statistical significance. Data Synthesis: Sixty-three studies met the criteria for our systematic review. No benefit was recorded in 45 studies, with 10 of these showing a trend towards harm and with two showing a trend towards benefit. Four studies reported harm with increased cancer deaths (n=2) and increased fractures (n=2). Two studies reported both a harmful as well as a beneficial outcome. A beneficial outcome was reported in 12 studies; 6 which studied vitamin D and three which investigated omega-3 fatty acids. While a benefit was reported in one study each which investigated Vitamin E, folic acid and Ginkgo biloba this benefit was not confirmed by larger and more adequately powered studies. Conclusions: With the possible exceptions of Vitamin D and omega-3 fatty acids there is no data to support the widespread use of dietary supplements in Westernized populations; indeed, many of these supplements may be harmful.

sec.title: Clinical Relevancy Statement
sec.p: The potential benefits and/or harm of nutrition supplements have significant clinical implications as more than half of the U.S. population takes nutrition supplements daily, and multivitamin-multimineral products are frequently prescribed by healthcare practitioners. The results of our study raise an alarm that this behavior may be harmful and that, with few exceptions, few data support the use of nutrition supplements.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A dietary supplement is defined as a product that is intended for use by humans to maintain and promote health and that contains 1 or more of the following ingredients: a vitamin, a mineral, a herb or other botanical, or an amino acid that is ingested in tablet, capsule, or liquid form.1 In the United States, dietary supplements are regulated under the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act (DSHEA) of 1994.1 This act assumes that supplements, unlike drugs and food additives, are safe and effective. The DSHEA limits the control that the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) can exert over the dietary supplement industry.

Epidemiological data and cohort studies have suggested that dietary and supplemental B vitamins, ascorbic acid, folic acid, carotenoids, and tocopherols are associated with a decreased risk of cardiovascular disease and cancer.2-8 Furthermore, numerous experimental studies have suggested favorable effects of several vitamins, minerals, and herbal products on oxidant damage, inflammation, immunity, DNA damage, and cell differentiation, proliferation, and apoptosis.9-11 On the basis of this evidence, together with television and magazine advertisements, information obtained on the Internet, articles in the lay press, and the recommendations of their physicians, a large proportion of the U.S. population takes a variety of vitamin, mineral, and herbal supplements daily in the hopes of promoting good health, preventing chronic diseases (such as heart disease and cancer), limiting the ravages of aging, and ultimately extending life. The National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 1999-2000 and other studies have demonstrated that over half the U.S. population regularly uses a dietary supplement, with >35% reporting the regular use of a multivitamin-multimineral (MVMM) product.12-14 Furthermore, at least half of supplement users report taking more than 1 supplement daily. According to the Nutrition Business Journal, annual sales of dietary supplements in the United States for 2008 were $25 billion.15 It has been estimated that 17% of this expenditure was spent on individual vitamins, 28% on MVMM, 14% on minerals, 11% on herbal supplements, and 31% on nonherbal supplements.16

More than 30,000 different dietary supplements are currently available in the United States.17 The most commonly used over-the-counter MVMM supplements contain at least 10 vitamins and 10 minerals usually at doses close to 100% of the recommend daily allowance (RDA = 2 standard deviations above the estimated average requirements). When combined with dietary intake, the total intake of selenium, zinc, phosphorus, magnesium, niacin, folic acid, and vitamins A, C, and E of supplement users in the United States exceeds 100% of the estimated average requirements (EAR), with the intake of vitamins C and E exceeding 700% of the EAR.12,14,16,18 The most common herbal medicines used in Western countries include ginkgo (Ginkgo biloba), St John’s wort (Hypericum perforatum), stinging nettle (Urtica dioica), saw palmetto, mistletoe, and garlic. Many of the supplements presently available in the United States have uncertain quality control in their manufacture, and the user has no assurance about what he or she is taking. In addition, an increasing number of supplements contain products grown or manufactured overseas, where product purity and quality may vary significantly compared with agents manufactured in the United States.19,20

Micronutrient deficiency, particularly vitamin A, and iron deficiency are a public health concern in more than half of all countries in the world, with most of the affected countries being in Africa or southeastern Asia.21,22 According to recent statistics from the World Health Organization (WHO), an estimated 250 million preschool children in the world have vitamin A deficiency, and 250,000–500,000 of such children go blind every year.21 Randomized controlled trials conducted in children in developing nations have demonstrated that vitamin A supplementation decreases morbidity and all-cause mortality.23-26 It is therefore likely that dietary supplements (particularly those containing vitamin A and iron) in children and pregnant women will have beneficial health outcomes in developing nations.27 However, the benefit of dietary supplements in nonpregnant adults in the United States and other Western nations is less clear. Given the fact that almost half of the U.S. population consumes dietary supplements on a regular basis, it is important to determine if indeed these substances meet the requirements as set out by the DSHEA, that is, they are safe and effective. An “influential review” of the benefits of vitamin supplements published in 2001 concluded that “a daily multivitamin that does not exceed the RDA of its components makes sense for most adults”; that “substantial evidence suggest that higher intake of folic acid, vitamin B6, vitamin B12 and vitamin D will benefit many people”; and that “vitamin E supplements are reasonable for most middle aged and older Americans who are at increased risk for coronary disease.”28 Since the publication of this review, a considerable number of randomized controlled trials testing the safety and efficacy of dietary supplements have been published.

The “gold-standard” approach to resolving whether a health practice offers benefit or harm to the public is through the conduct of well-designed and adequately powered randomized controlled trials. Randomized controlled trials are the only trial design for which causal inference can be established. Our goal was to systematically review the literature to identify those randomized controlled trials that investigated clinically relevant outcomes from the use of dietary supplements and then to synthesize and summarize these data.

sec.title: Identification of Trials
sec.p: Our aim was to identify all relevant randomized controlled trials (RCTs) that evaluated the benefits and safety of dietary supplements. We restricted this analysis to human, nonpregnant adults and only included studies that evaluated clinical end points (including risk of acute myocardial infarction, stroke, cardiovascular death, risk of cancer, cancer recurrence, cancer death, risk of type 2 diabetes, risk of fractures, cognitive function, and all-cause mortality). We excluded studies performed in undernourished populations, patient groups with specific nutrition diseases, and pediatric and pregnant patients. We excluded studies that enrolled <200 participants as such studies are likely to have unbalanced randomization of confounders and do not have statistical power to reliably detect a treatment effect (type II error).29 Furthermore, as it is likely that there would be a time delay between the consumption of a dietary supplement and discernable clinical outcomes, we excluded studies that were less than 1 year in duration. We recorded all outcomes for those studies reported in multiple publications. We used a multimethod approach to identify relevant studies for this review. Both authors independently searched the National Library of Medicine’s MEDLINE database for relevant studies in any language published from 1966 to December 2010 using the following Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) and keywords: dietary supplement or vitamins or Vitamin A or Vitamin B6 or Vitamin B12 or Vitamin D or Vitamin E or ascorbic acid or thiamine or folic acid or selenium(selenium compounds) or glucosamine or fatty acids, omega-3 or Ginkgo biloba or St John’s Wort (Hypericum perforatum) or Stinging Nettle (Urtica dioica) or Saw Palmetto or Milk Thistle or Garlic or Echinacea AND (limit) adult AND (limit) randomized controlled trial (publication type). In addition, we searched Embase and the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. Bibliographies of all selected articles and review articles that included information on dietary supplements were reviewed for other relevant articles. In addition, we searched the “gray literature” to avoid any reporting bias; this included studies published in abstracts only. This search strategy was employed iteratively, until no new potential citations were found on review of the reference lists of retrieved articles. Our review was performed according to the guidelines proposed by the QUOROM group.30

sec.title: Data Extraction and Analysis
sec.p: Both authors independently abstracted data from all studies using a standardized form. Data were abstracted on study design, study size, study setting, patient population, the country where the study was performed, the year of publication, the dietary supplement(s) investigated and dosages, the duration of the study/observation period, and all outcomes. We provided the outcomes of each study individually and in a semiquantitative manner classified the outcomes of each study as nonbeneficial, beneficial, or harmful according to whether the end point(s) of interest in each study reached statistical significance. We were then able to determine the number of studies that showed no benefit, benefit, or harm overall for each dietary supplement.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The initial search strategy generated 6224 citations; of these, 3322 were excluded as the study was not relevant to our review. The abstracts of the remaining 2902 studies were reviewed. A further 1510 were excluded because of study design (no placebo arm, inadequate randomization), duplicate publication, or a failure to report an outcome variable of interest. An additional 1340 studies were excluded because of inadequate sample size, inadequate duration of follow-up, or nontarget population. An additional 11 studies were identified from the bibliographies of the selected articles and review articles. No studies were identified that were published in abstracts only.

Sixty-three studies met the criteria for our systematic review. These studies enrolled a total of 428,357 patients with an average of 6693 patients per study and a mean duration of 4.7 years. These studies are summarized in Table 1. The included studies evaluated β-carotene; vitamins A, B6, B12, C, D, and E; folic acid; calcium; selenium; ω-3 fatty acids; G biloba; glucosamine; saw palmetto; and milk thistle. No randomized controlled studies investigating St John’s wort, stinging nettle, echinacea, or garlic met our inclusion criteria. No benefit was recorded in 45 studies, with 10 of these showing a trend toward harm and 2 showing a trend toward benefit. Four studies reported harm, with an increased risk of cancer and cancer deaths in the Carotene and Retinol Efficacy Trial (CARET) and the Norwegian Vitamin Trial II (NORVIT II) studies and an increased risk of fractures in the 2 studies that investigated high-dose once-yearly vitamin D. The Nutritional Cancer Prevention Study (selenium supplementation) demonstrated both benefit (less cancer) and harm (increased risk of type 2 diabetes). The lower risk of cancer with selenium supplementation, however, was not confirmed in the much larger Selenium and Vitamin E Cancer Prevention Trial (SELECT). Similarly, the Calcium Polyp Prevention Study demonstrated both a benefit (reduced fractures and reduced polyps) and harm (increased acute myocardial infarction). A beneficial outcome was reported in 12 studies; 6 studied vitamin D and 3 investigated ω-3 fatty acids. The benefits of vitamin D appeared to be dose dependent. Although a benefit was reported in 1 study each that investigated vitamin E, folic acid, and G biloba, this benefit was not confirmed by larger and more adequately powered studies.

fn.p: AMI, acute myocardial infarction; AREDS, Age-Related Eye Disease Study; ATBC, Alpha-Tocopherol, Beta Carotene; CAD, coronary artery disease; CARET, Carotene and Retinol Efficacy Trial; CVS, cardiovascular event; DATATOP, Deprenyl and Tocopherol Antioxidative Therapy of Parkinsonism trial; FACIT, Folic Acid and Carotid Intima-Media Thickness trial; F, female; GEM, Ginkgo Evaluation of Memory; GISSI, Gruppo Italiano per lo Studio della Sopravvivenza nell’Infarto Miocardico; HOPE, Heart Outcomes Prevention Evaluation; JELIS, Japan EPA Lipid Intervention Study; LDL, low-density lipoprotein; M, male; MMV, multivitamin and mineral; MRC, Medical Research Council; NH, nursing home; NORVIT, Norwegian Vitamin Trial; OPAL, Older People and n-3 Long-Chain Polyunsaturated Fatty Acids study; REACT, Roche European American Cataract Trial; RECORD, Randomised Evaluation of Calcium or Vitamin D trial; SEARCH, Study of the Effectiveness of Additional Reductions in Cholesterol and Homocysteine; SELECT, Selenium and Vitamin E Cancer Prevention Trial; SU.VI.MAX, Supplémentation en Vitamines et Minéraux Antioxydants; VISP, Vitamin Intervention for Stroke Prevention; WAFACS, Women’s Antioxidant and Folic Acid Cardiovascular Study; WAVE, Women’s Angiographic Vitamin and Estrogen trial; WENBIT, Western Norway B Vitamin Intervention Trial.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The results of our study demonstrate that with the possible exceptions of vitamin D (in elderly patients) and ω-3 fatty acids (in patients with cardiovascular disease), no data support the widespread use of dietary supplements in Westernized populations; indeed, the data suggest that certain commonly used dietary supplements (β-carotene, vitamin A, and vitamin E) may be harmful. Our findings are supported by a meta-analysis by Bjelakovic and colleagues,31 who demonstrated that β-carotene (relative risk [RR], 1.07; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.02–1.11), vitamin A (1.16; 1.1–1.24), and vitamin E (1.04; 1.01–1.07) singly or in combination significantly increased mortality. According to the Institute of Medicine’s (IOM’s) categorization of vitamin D status based on serum 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25OHD),32 data from the most recent NHANES (2001-2006) indicate that only 8% of the U.S. population are “at risk of vitamin D deficiency” (serum 25OHD <30 nmol/L). 33 This finding may partly explain the limited benefit of vitamin D supplementation. In addition, vitamin D3 in doses of <700 IU/d appears to have no beneficial effect on health outcomes. Data from a limited number of studies suggest that vitamin D3 in a dose in excess of 699 IU/d may reduce the risk of falls, osteoporotic fractures, and the risk of cancer in elderly patients.34-36 However, high-dose vitamin D given once yearly appears paradoxically to increase the risk of fractures. Calcium supplementation alone may increase the risk of myocardial infarction.37 It is important to note that most multivitamins contain <700 IU of vitamin D3. The IOM’s updated (2010) dietary reference intake for vitamin D lists the RDA as 600 IU/d for adults younger than 70 years and 800 IU/d for adults older than 70 years.32 However, the International Osteoporosis Foundation in its most recent guidelines (2010) suggests that the average vitamin D requirement for older adults is between 800 and 1000 IU/d.38 Because of the conflicting data and varying recommendations, additional studies are required before vitamin D supplementation can be widely recommended.32,35,36,38-41 Supplementation with ω-3 fatty acids (2–4 g/d) appears to be effective in reducing angina, acute myocardial infarction, and cardiovascular death in patients with cardiovascular disease.

Dietary supplements in Westernized populations are frequently used to compensate for a poor diet and an unhealthy lifestyle. Dietary supplements do not contain proteins, essential fatty acids, fiber, phytochemicals, and other important compounds (both known and unknown) found in fruits and vegetables. Although there are limited scientific data to recommend the use of dietary supplements, an emerging body of evidence suggests that lifestyle modification, which includes dietary interventions and exercise, improves health outcomes.42-47

The practice of medicine as taught in U.S. medical schools is grounded in the scientific method and stresses the use of evidence in patient care decisions. Before a drug is administered to humans, its efficacy and safety must be established in well-designed trials, and the FDA must approve its use. We believe that dietary supplements should be held to the same level of evidence and regulatory standards.

Our article has a number of limitations. Most notably, the studies included in our systematic review were very heterogeneous, involving many different patient groups and many supplementation regimens, with differing study designs and widely differing end points. We were therefore unable to perform a traditional meta-analysis but rather presented the outcomes of each study in a semiquantitative manner (beneficial, neural, or harmful). We believe that this is a useful approach to answering the important question posed.48 Furthermore, our findings are limited by the methodological quality of the original studies, and for many supplements, limited or no “high-quality” data were available. However, we believe that the findings of our study are valid in that very little experimental data support the notion that vitamin and mineral supplements have beneficial pharmacological properties in those individuals not deficient in the particular vitamin or mineral that is supplemented.

In conclusion, the results of our study provide little evidence to support the current levels of dietary supplement use in the United States and other Western nations. Additional long-term RCTs are required to determine the health benefits of dietary supplements. However, as cost constraints preclude RCTs that extend decades, prospective cohort and case control studies are needed to discern the impact of supplements on chronic, long-term health outcomes.
